content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: A clash-sized doable challenge, with a logical case build-up with respect to possible errors one can encounter.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like this, lots of edge cases to consider

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good clash, good idea for deleting zeros (two places).

Please don't use i as the string name in the loop. The Java (and presumably C# and others) template of the stub uses i for the iteration counter when defining the loop.

The input is space-separated strings in a single line, but (again) in Java, the String input of the loop uses a nextLine() method as opposed to next() to get it, so the first loop gets the string  "12 345 6789" and the next iteration breaks. 
I suggest you either forget the loop and just pass a single string for the user to split, or put each string on a separate line, e.g.:
3
12
345
6789

Once I fixed what the stub generated, it's a good puzzle though.

Goal / cases
* Please change "made out of" to "by joining".

* The cases do not seem to cover the situation where the *first* set of middle digits start with 0, e.g. 80247, 6001, 3000509. Please EITHER
   • add such cases, and explain the treatment in Goal section (drop the leading zeros if it is the first set, otherwise all zeros should be kept?),
   OR
   • add a constraint stating that it is guaranteed such cases are not tested.
   I myself prefer the first option.

Input
* Please add "separated by a space" to the line 2 description.

Thanks.

Damn, I actually forgot about leading zeroes, the whole concept behind using numbers instead of strings was to throw players off by tricking some of them into parsing the inputs as numbers. But you're absolutely right!

I've also added more information regarding leading zeroes handling on the integers, and applied your other suggestions; it makes a lot more rules like this! How about now?
I see, thanks! I've changed the entry in the stub generator to "number" :)
I suggest to include numbers where the middle digits are all 0s in the last test and the last validator.
Done, on the first integer and the one before the last. :)
